body:
@leerho sorry for late review. I like version B most. You don't have to duplicate code, because you don't need `MemoryImpl`, you can return `WritableMemoryImpl` from static factory methods which return `Memory` (read-only) as well. And read-only flag also won't be needed in this case, because Java compiler will ensure there are no illegal accesses, if we follow two simple rules: don't explicitly cast any `Memory` instance to `WritableMemory`, and don't use `Memory` as generic parameter.

I believe it's important to keep read-only and writable interfaces separate, I explained above why: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3892#issuecomment-279173943
üëç
Opened #3957 with conflicts fixed, otherwise unchanged.
thx @fjy and @nishantmonu51 for review

@leerho `Memory` asked to be stateless and implementation-less to allow implementation based on completely different principles than Unsafe, e. g. something backed by network-attached storage: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3892#issuecomment-279304755

However it is not necessary now, because there is no reaction from @weijietong and probably he doesn't need #3716 anymore. Anyway, it could be fixed relatively easily later, if needed, because it doesn't incur API changes.
Also if there is just one writing thread, synchronization inside simple aggregators (long/double/float) is not needed at all.

Parag Jain asked,

"@tdingus are you hitting this - #1274
 Do you have a single segment in the cluster ? Are you getting any error while deleting ?
"

Yes. I have a single segment in the cluster. I don't see any error log while deleting. If I should expect any error log, where should I look for it.

thanks

Yes. I have a single segment in the cluster. I don't see any error log while deleting. If I should expect any error log, where should I look for it.thanks
      From: Parag Jain <notifications@github.com>
 To: druid-io/druid <druid@noreply.github.com> 
Cc: tdingus <tdingus@yahoo.com>; Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>
 Sent: Tuesday, February 21, 2017 4:55 PM
 Subject: Re: [druid-io/druid] can't disable segments with DELETE datasource kill=false any more (#2467)
   
@tdingus are you hitting this - #1274
Do you have a single segment in the cluster ? Are you getting any error while deleting ?‚Äî
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

you can check the coordinator logs for any error after you send the kill request. However, I think unfortunately you are hitting #1274 and even after the segment is marked as unused, coordinator will still think it is present. However, it should not be a problem for production systems when you have multiple segments getting created and removed as per the load/drop rules

However, lets say you really want to **completely clean** the cluster because you are running integration tests or something then as per the current druid code base you can do this by -

1. stop coordinator node and delete all entires in the druid_segments table in the metadata store
2. stop historical node and delete everything inside the directory pointed by `druid.segmentCache.locations` at historical node
3. start coordinator and historical nodes

**REMEMBER THIS WILL DELETE EVERYTHING FROM DRUID CLUSTER, YOU WILL LOOSE ALL YOUR DATA**
üëç

@leventov thanks for your review. Addressed some of your comments.

I don't know why I can't add an inline reply for [your comment](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3939#discussion_r102354444). That part is not what I changed. I just changed that ```take()``` method throws a RuntimeException instead of an InterruptedException.

@leventov 

Sorry, I had completely misinterpreted a previous statement of yours:

> regarding x2 less classes, I meant that the separation between read-only and writable implementations is not needed. There are only writable implementations. The only thing that e. g. map() does is delegation to mapWritable(), and return the read-only interface. It is safe on the type-system level with very little precautions. Your approach with runtime separation provides extra safety, if you want to keep this safety - yes, you either still have x2 classes, or e. g. have a boolean flag "writable" and check it guarded by assertion, e. g. in checkOffset() method, along with the offset check.

Now that I read it again carefully and in the context of your latest comments, I understand what happened.  I interpreted "implementations" as "classes that have been implemented", assuming the looser interpretation of "implementations". What you meant by "implementations" is "concrete classes" as opposed to an "abstract classes".  And since in the same paragraph, you suggested having a boolean flag, the looser interpretation of "implementations" directly leads to Version C! 

I will go back to Version B, but with ONE concrete WritableMemory class and no Memory concrete class :)

In your statement: 

> if we ... don't explicitly cast any `Memory` instance to `WritableMemory`...

Who are "we"?  You and I certainly won't do that.  But what is there to prevent a user from doing that?  :)  

And to make sure I understand what you mean, could you give me a code example of what you mean by:

> and don't use `Memory` as generic parameter.

Thank you for your clarification on the need for the stateless root. I may as well keep the root stateless.

I have completed some initial characterization tests on the performance of this new hierarchy based Version C. (I don't expect the different versions to vary much since they should all collapse down to a single object after compilation and JIT).  It is a little better than the current Memory implementation based on an `interface`, but still not as good as pure static calls, which will still be possible if a `WritableMemory` object is passed and the user goes to the trouble.

**Current Memory Performance**

![rwmemoryheapdirect_21feb17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12941506/23196105/62236946-f86c-11e6-85d5-3bdc01ef895e.png)

**Version C Memory Performance**

![rwmemorycheapdirect_21feb17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12941506/23196119/7b7ec836-f86c-11e6-8982-343351b57aef.png)

**Memory Performance using Static Methods Wrapping Unsafe**

![rwmemoryheapdirectviastaticunsafe_21feb17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12941506/23196138/a9dfe016-f86c-11e6-9af3-b6733abc2e04.png)
@jihoonson and about `poll` vs `take()` - before you explained, that timeout 0 means "no wait", but `take()` is blocking.

> Who are "we"? You and I certainly won't do that. But what is there to prevent a user from doing that? :)

DataSketches contributors and Druid contributors. It could be enforced even by adding a custom "Regexp" rule to checkstyle config, that looks for `(WritableMemory)` and `Memory>`
@leventov ah, I got your point. That's also not what I changed, but I clarified it.
Release notes  - http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0-rc1/ is not available. Can you please fix it.
@mszone, 0.10.0-rc1 hasn't been released yet, this issue is just a place to draft the notes for when it does get released. This will likely be soon.

I manual execute below sql `create table druid_meta.druid_supervisors (
	id BIGINT(20) not NULL,
    spec_id VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    created_date VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    payload LONGBLOB  NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (id)
);
CREATE INDEX idx_druid_supervisors_spec_id ON druid_meta.druid_supervisors(spec_id);`

the issue disappeared

@jon-wei I simply added a new ```takeBatch()``` method to BlockingPool which is ```checkAndDrain()``` you mentioned. After thinking about this for a while, I decided to add it because this issue focuses on guaranteeing the atomicity when acquiring merge buffers, and it cannot be achieved without ```takeBatch()```. But I still believe that we need to improve and maybe redesign BlockingPool.

Sorry for going back and forth. Would you and other reviewers @himanshug @leventov mind reviewing again please?
@drcrallen added a blurb on downgrade in lookups.md

@gianm @jon-wei 
somewhat related to this PR....

after this PR our builds for hadoop indexer test failed to run the groupBy query and failed with exception message "Grouping resources exhausted" from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/query/groupby/epinephelinae/GroupByMergingQueryRunnerV2.java#L301 with no indication of what the problem was. I added some disk space by `druid.query.groupBy.maxOnDiskStorage` and the problem disappeared.
that said, it might not be so simple for a regular druid user to understand.
should we change https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/query/groupby/epinephelinae/SpillingGrouper.java#L119 to 
```
throw new ISE(ex, "no space to spill results, please increase druid.query.groupBy.maxOnDiskStorage or druid.processing.buffer.sizeBytes");
```
Yeah that message could be better. I think nothing else other than temporary-storage-full could cause that, so might as well add that to the error message.
There's a similar message in GroupByRowProcessor that could be changed too
Hmm, something weird going on with the guice injection test. Looking into it.
Pushed a fix.

@gianm wondering why would we modify the message at both places instead of throwing exception with correct message in SpillingGrouper ... is there a case when throwing exception there is not desirable?

@himanshug thank you for the review and merge.
@gianm @leventov @jon-wei if you have more comments on the newly added part, please feel free to tell me. I'll do in a follow-up pr.

@himanshug I guess I avoided exceptions because `grouper.aggregate` returns false normally and I didn't want to have the overhead of exceptions in that code path. For example that's how BufferGrouper tells SpillingGrouper that it needs to be spilled. Usually I try to avoid exceptions for control flow in query code like that.

How about changing the return type from `boolean` to something that includes a message or a reason?
@himanshug @jon-wei could you please review this?

@sirpkt, are you still interested in pursuing this patch? A lot has changed since you submitted it but I'm interested in helping figure out how to integrate this work into Druid. It would help with another goal I have, which is is to generalize extractionFns in two ways for benefit of the SQL layer:

1. taking multiple arguments (this patch is relevant)
2. able to return types other than strings

Let me know if you'd like to keep working on the first one, otherwise I may pick it up. If you work on it I can do a review.
@pjain1 @b-slim @drcrallen Any suggestion?
@leventov sure, I'll have some time to start reviewing this tomorrow

When search with a not existed dimension, querying at IncrementalIndex, the result is not empty.
When search with a not existed dimension, querying at QueryableIndex, the result is empty. 

The result should always be empty

@gianm @himanshug Tested these changes in stg environment, puller/pusher/killer looks good. Tested with diff combinations:
 a) data source with segments stored using new format
 b) data source with segments stored using old format
 c) data source with segments stored using mixed format (new + old format).

@himanshug @b-slim I rewritten `LifecycleLock` so that it doesn't block in `canStop()`, awaiting for `exitStart()`, because it would cause a dead lock, if `exitStart()` is not called for any reason (it should always be called in a finally block in `start()`, so this "reason" is a bug anyway). Instead, `canStop()` throws an exception now, if it sees that `exitStart()` is not yet called. It shouldn't cause transient failures, because `start()` and `stop()` of any lifecycled object are expected to be called from a single thread, or at least being synchronized externally, like in the `Lifecycle` class. If this is not the case, i. e. `start()` and `stop()` are called truly concurrently from different threads, it also looks like a bug.
@jon-wei, please update the log msg and then feel free to merge it yourself since there's enough +1s

@gianm , I doc the bug at #3972

@himanshug  according to your idea, through looping asking segments from historical/realtime nodes background ,how to avoid holding stale segment infos on coordinator/brokers side if not looped in time while a query occurred ?
Posting here to confirm that choosing the `ruby` spec for timestampSpec seems to work fine. As of yet this spec isn't documented yet.

@weijietong brokers/coordinators would not have stale segment info because they are running inifinite (no wait) loop to get latest segment information from historical/realtime nodes.... historical/realtime nodes "hold" the request till there is new information to provide or timeout provided in the request is reached.

@drcrallen also just realized that lookup management is being done by all coordinators and not just by the leader. though it wouldn't cause any harm but its certainly not necessary and significant waste of resources. was there a reason to run it on all coordinators?
It's supposed to be just the leader. If it's all thats a bug
also is it possible to have a "reset()" method on LifecycleLock so that same instance can be reused for services which are started/stopped multiple time ?

@drcrallen ok, i double checked and indeed all coordinators run the lookup management. given that, it was unintentional I will do a follow up PR to fix that.
filed https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3975
